prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for asking my bulimic roommate to control herself?
I (F20) have been living with my roommate (F20) for about a year now. We’ve already made plans to move out and live with other people in a few months (unrelated to any of this). For the most part, she’s a really good roommate; she pays everything on time, cleans the whole apartment, is very quiet, and even though we aren’t friends per se we are friendly and get along pretty well.


She doesn’t really cook, and her side of the fridge/her cupboards are pretty much bare (like she literally just has condiments in the fridge right now). I enjoy cooking and am on a bit of a budget (I support myself) so I cook 3 meals a day, 7 days a week (since I can’t afford to eat out). 


Starting when we first moved in, I started noticing things were off with my food. Not that things were missing (although sometimes I would have less of something than I thought) but also that I would sometimes have more, of a different product than I remember buying (ie going to eat some crackers and them being kinda whole grain-y despite the box saying original). I didn’t really think much of it, or just assumed I was being absent minded.


Lately though, it’s been getting much worse and it’s clear she’s taking my food and trying to replace it (hence the products sometimes being slightly different). I’ve gone into the cupboards and found unopened packages of things that I KNOW I’ve already opened.


Last week I confronted her about this and she broke down crying and told me she’s been bulimic for a wrong time, she knows it’s wrong, but she can’t help binging on my food sometimes, blah blah. Also that she doesn’t want to be like this but she’s stuck on a waitlist for treatment. She was very upset and apologetic but I was still mad at her. I told her that I’m sorry she has that issue but it shouldn’t be my problem and if she needs to eat she can just buy her own food since her parents support her. She pointed out that she replaces everything she takes but it still bothers me knowing that someone is eating MY food. I understand there’s something wrong with her but it’s not like she can’t control herself at the grocery store and eats right off the shelves, or at restaurants takes from other people’s tables. I told her that and I don’t understand why this is any different; it’s not socially acceptable to take other people’s property regardless of what’s wrong with you. 


She cried in her room for a long time and we haven’t spoken or made eye contact since then, although I’m trying to be nice. I feel bad but I also don’t think I actually did anything wrong. We’re both 20, IMO it’s not unreasonable to expect her to control herself. Like do I want to eat a whole box of cookies? Sure, but I don’t because I know better. I’m just asking her to exercise the same restraint here. 


Am I the asshole?

"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author (F20) is in the wrong for confronting their bulimic roommate about taking their food.

First, the roommate has a known eating disorder and is on a waitlist for treatment. She's taking food from the author's supplies and trying to replace it. The author confronts her, and the roommate apologizes but explains her condition. The author feels justified in asking her to control herself and mentions that the roommate can buy her own food since she's supported by her parents.

So, the key points here are: the roommate has a mental health issue, the author is upset about their own food being taken, and they expect self-control. The author's argument is that it's not acceptable to take others' property regardless of the situation, similar to not taking from stores or others' tables. The roommate, however, is struggling with a disorder that affects her self-control.

Now, considering if the author is in the wrong. On one hand, the author has a right to their property and can be upset about it being taken without consent. They are also on a budget and cooking for themselves, which adds to the frustration. On the other hand, the roommate has a mental health condition that impairs her ability to control her actions. The author's response might be seen as harsh given the roommate's vulnerability. However, the author isn't blaming her for the condition but is setting a boundary.

The question is whether the author's demand for self-control is unreasonable. The author points out that the roommate can buy her own food, which is a practical solution. The roommate might need more support or alternative solutions, but the author isn't necessarily wrong for setting a boundary. The situation is complicated by the roommate's mental health, but the author's actions are about their own property and the expectation of mutual respect in a shared living space.

Considering all this, the author isn't the asshole. They have a valid concern and are asking for respect of their belongings. The roommate's issue is more about needing help managing her condition, not the author being in the wrong.
